What is the importance of cellular respiration for living organisms?
Who were the tribunes and what were their main powers as elected officials?
Why is the concentration of salts in blood plasma maintained at a practically constant level?

What comparisons can you draw among the various political transformations and crises of authority that occurred across Afro-Eurasia in the fourteenth century? How were they similar, and how were they different?
What is biotechnology?
What key elements of Roman religion can you connect to the chapter’s earlier discussion of the Roman family?
What is motion sickness?
For what purpose do people harden their bodies?
The action of many antibiotics is based on their influence on gene regulation in bacteria. Why do they not affect the regulation of genes in humans when consumed by humans?
What is the role of the autonomic nervous system in the human body?
What is the structure of the kidneys?

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

The Department for Combating Corruption is an organizational unit of the Office of the Government of the Czech Republic. The activities of this department must be in accordance with the Statute and Rules of Procedure of the Government Council for the Coordination of the Fight against Corruption. The Council was established by a government resolution of 30 July 2017.

Ivan Bartoš mentions the Working Group for the Assessment of Legislation on Anti-Corruption Measures . It was founded by the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, Radek Vondráček (ANO). The aim of this group is to find consensus in the approval of anti-corruption laws by means of discussion forums for members of political parties, non-profit organizations, and the public. Those interested in discussing drafts of current laws should meet approximately once a month, and the first meeting, held on February 1, 2018, was attended by representatives of several political parties.

There is no mention in the public media space of the existence of the aforementioned version, which would allow for, for example, an information embargo.

SECTION B:

The government proposal (.pdf) for an amendment to Act No. 106/1999 Coll. , on free access to information, adds the following sentence to Section 2: "The Act shall not apply to the provision of information on ongoing criminal proceedings and persons participating in them, with the exception of information on court decisions on the merits." (.pdf, p. 28). The amendment to the Act would thus make it impossible to access information on ongoing criminal proceedings under Act No. 106/1999 Coll., including procedural decisions in the proceedings. Therefore, if a question were asked, it would be completely outside the competence of the Act and there would be no need to handle it.

In the current version of the Act on Free Access to Information , Section 11 already contains a ban on providing information on ongoing criminal proceedings (i.e. everything up to the decision in the case). The law therefore required that the request be processed in such a way that the information is not provided. However, this rule is broken by the case law ( judgment no. 1 As 44/2010 – 103, point 36) of the Supreme Administrative Court, which requires obliged entities to consider each individual case and, depending on the circumstances, to allow the provision of information on ongoing criminal proceedings where the failure to provide information cannot be justified by an “urgent social need”. Courts may therefore provide information on ongoing criminal proceedings despite the statutory ban, if the failure to provide information is not necessary.

According to the explanatory report (.pdf, p. 127) of the government amendment, this situation led to " a far-reaching burden on criminal justice authorities, who always had to justify in detail why information could not be provided (if they did not provide it), with difficulties arising from the question of how to argue without using the information itself".

If the government amendment were to enter into force, the obligation of authorities involved in criminal proceedings to provide reasons for (not) providing information during the proceedings, as established by case law, would cease. Only the obligation to provide information on the decision on the merits would be maintained. The public would thus not have access to information on ongoing criminal proceedings and procedural decisions, which are often crucial for the development of the proceedings. According to the NSS (point 38), providing information on ongoing criminal proceedings is often in the public interest, especially in cases involving criminal acts committed by officials or public officials. Such a case is, among others, the procedural resolution of the High Court in Prague in the David Rath case, by which the High Court rejected wiretapping as illegal.

The discussion of the amendment to the law in the third reading was included on the agenda of the 20th meeting and should take place on November 14, 2018.

SECTION C:

The government submitted a draft amendment to the Civil Service Act to the Chamber of Deputies on 26 March 2018. The amendment was approved by the Chamber of Deputies in the third reading. At the 19th meeting of the Chamber of Deputies on 13 September, the chairman of the Pirates, Ivan Bartoš, questioned Prime Minister Andrej Babiš about the amendment to the Civil Service Act. The Pirates criticize the amendment on the grounds that, according to them, it strengthens political influence in the state administration and may increase the risk of dismissing inconvenient civil servants.

Prime Minister Andrej Babiš stated in his response to the interpellation: "So you are creating an atmosphere here that we have been doing some kind of purge. When you are not in it and you are a minister and you have a state secretary who does whatever he wants, does not go to work, is antisocial, threatens a mother who has a home office, and we have one like that, a state secretary. And when you have a subordinate who is not working well, who has caused damage, then try to explain to me how we should replace him. And we have been fighting this for a long time."

He continued: "It is absurd for the minister to be there in the number, for the state secretary to actually do whatever he wants. So that he cannot de facto, if he is dissatisfied with a direct subordinate, so that he cannot replace him. So try talking to Adam Vojtěch, he has probably been in charge there since February. He asked for some disciplinary proceedings and now we are waiting for the highest official. Because the highest official, Mr. Postránecký, is more than the government. More! That is absolutely top!"

The Minister of Health, Adam Vojtěch, commented on the amendment to the Civil Service Act at the 13th meeting of the Chamber of Deputies on May 23, 2018, where he stated: "I am appearing before you on behalf of a ministry that has long been affected by the highest staff shortage of all central state administration bodies in the Czech Republic. In 2016, it was 65%, the occupancy rate in the ministry. In 2017, I took over the Ministry of Health in a situation where every third employee was missing, when some departments had only department heads without rank-and-file employees. In this complicated situation, I was supposed to fulfill a program, which, however, was slowly becoming impossible to implement with anyone. And unfortunately, it is not possible to this day. When I was looking for the cause of these problems after I took office at the ministry, I conducted a questionnaire among employees, a relatively extensive questionnaire survey, in which over 80% of employees participated. And I am deeply convinced that the main reason for this catastrophic situation in the healthcare sector is the long-term inability to effectively staff manage employees from the highest position in the ministry, i.e. from the position of State Secretary." He further stated: "I filed a disciplinary complaint against the State Secretary on February 12. The disciplinary committee has not even met to date - and I say again that we are facing a fundamental personnel destabilization and personnel shortage at the Ministry of Health. I therefore believe that disciplinary proceedings are not a completely appropriate tool for resolving the unsystematic, purposeful and often irrational behavior of responsible persons." He also mentioned in his speech the case where the State Secretary at the Ministry of Health illegally delayed the selection process for the position of Director of the State Institute for Drug Control.

It is therefore clear from the quotes that both are complaining about the protracted disciplinary proceedings and the impossibility of immediately implementing a change. They are not saying – as Bartoš suggests in his statement – that a change cannot be implemented at all, on the contrary, they are trying to achieve change through specific steps (disciplinary proceedings).

Let us add that, according to Section 60 of the Civil Service Act, a state secretary can only be dismissed in cases defined by law (e.g., termination of service, medical incapacity, etc.). In addition, this is possible if " the service evaluation contains a conclusion that he achieved unsatisfactory results in service". However, such a service evaluation is done once a year and if it is unsatisfactory, a new one is done in 6 months. If he reaches the fourth level of evaluation twice, i.e. "unsatisfactory", he can be dismissed, which is also explained in his opinion by the "super-official" Postránecký. Thus, the dismissal process takes at least a year and a half.

According to Section 60, paragraph 4 of this Act, service also ends on the day the decision on disciplinary action in the form of dismissal or dismissal becomes legally binding. However, it must be taken into account that, according to the Administrative Code, it is possible to appeal against the decision of the first-instance disciplinary committee to the second-instance disciplinary committee, and only then does the decision become legally binding.

SECTION D:

Chairman Bartoš (Pirates) is referring to the amendment to the Civil Service Act. The amendment proposal was submitted by the government on March 26, 2018.

Documents that demonstrate the European Commission's critical stance on the amendment were published on June 7, 2018 by the iRozhlas.cz server. Specifically, it is a letter (.pdf) addressed to the Deputy Minister of the Interior for the Civil Service, Josef Postránecký . The letter states that, based on a meeting on March 20, 2018, both parties reached a consensus on the need for further amendments to the draft Civil Service Act. The first part of the letter summarizes the commission's conclusions from the Report on the Czech Republic 2018 ( .pdf, p. 37 ). The criticism was directed at the administrative burden resulting from the proposal, the inability to attract experts from the academic and private sectors. The letter also mentions a large number of dismissals in leading positions after the new government took office, which does not correspond to the desired depoliticization of the state administration ( .pdf, p. 1 ).

This part of the letter is crucial: " We therefore remain concerned about key elements of the proposal. For example, the shift to somewhat lower requirements for second rounds of selection procedures for management positions, the possibility of dismissing managers based on a ' sufficient ' evaluation result, the possibility of dismissing civil servants based on two performance evaluations within a 40-day period, and the deprivation of managers from the possibility of filing an objection to performance evaluations." ( .pdf, p. 2 - translation by the iRozhlas.cz server used).

The European Commission's criticism was directed at changes in the evaluation of civil servants' work and the shortening of the period between individual evaluations.

The extension of the minimum period of 40 days between individual assessments to 60 days, or in the case of an extraordinary assessment after a previous assessment with an unsatisfactory result to 90 days, was presented in an amendment by Kateřina Valachová (ČSSD) ( docx, pp. 4 and 10 ). Her amendment was adopted .

Minister Dostálová (ANO) submitted an amendment to Section 60, paragraph 3 ( .docx, page 1 ):

"X. In Section 60, paragraph 3, first and second sentences, the words ", State Secretary" are inserted after the words "Deputy for Civil Service".

X. In Section 60, the following sentence is added at the end of paragraph 3: "A proposal to dismiss the Deputy for Civil Service and the Human Resources Director of the Civil Service Section shall be submitted to the Government by the Minister of the Interior, a proposal to dismiss the State Secretary shall be submitted to the Government by the relevant minister or the head of the Government Office after discussion with the Deputy for Civil Service."

According to Dostálová's amendment, the dismissal of state secretaries is therefore possible based on a government decision following the recommendation of the minister, as Bartoš states in his statement.

The expansion of the scale and conditions of personal evaluation was regulated by the proposal in Section 155 (. pdf, p. 24 ), among other things, it planned to expand the evaluation scale from 4 to 5 categories:

, ,3) The performance evaluation must contain a conclusion on whether the civil servant achieved in the service

a) excellent results,

b) very good results,

c ) good results,

d ) satisfactory results, or

(e ) unsatisfactory results.”

The proposal therefore implies that the evaluation scale has been expanded. To terminate the employment relationship, it is "enough" to obtain a rating of d) and e), in the words of Chairman Bartoš, " a five or a four".

The initial wording of the draft amendment regulated the conditions for dismissal from service in Section 60, Article 1, Part b): " the service evaluation contains a conclusion that the official achieved unsatisfactory or satisfactory results in service" ( .pdf, p. 16 ). In this case, no amendment proposal (.pdf) was submitted that would specifically change this provision. It can be said that the possibility of dismissing an official from service for a satisfactory ("four") evaluation thus remained in the proposal, although (as of November 1, 2018) we cannot confirm this with the press, which the Senate should now have. The EC's reprimand in this case was not corrected by the amendments, and we therefore assess the statement of Chairman Bartoš as untrue.

SECTION E:

Bartoš is probably referring to Babiš's first minority government from December 2017 to July 2018, which did not gain the confidence of the Chamber of Deputies. Its draft amendment to the Civil Service Act was submitted to the Chamber on March 26, 2018, i.e. 2 months after submitting his resignation.

Given the terminology ("the first thing the government started to address"), it is more of a figure of speech than a factual statement that it should be the first law submitted. However, it is worth adding that this was not the first government bill since taking office . Between December 13, 2017 and March 26, 2018, the government submitted an amendment to the Act on the CNB, an amendment to the Act on the Transfer of Ownership, an amendment to the Act on the Organization and Implementation of Social Security, or an amendment to the Act on Pension Insurance. Even the Ministry of the Interior, as the representative of the proposer, did not submit an amendment to the Act on Civil Service as the first part of its agenda; it was preceded, for example, by an amendment to the Act on Elections to the Parliament of the Czech Republic.

In April 2018, the European Commission criticized the government's draft amendment to the Civil Service Act. As we read in a letter from European Commissioner for Employment Marianne Thyssen to the Deputy Minister of the Interior for the Civil Service, Josef Postránecký: " We therefore remain concerned about key elements of the proposal. For example, the shift to somewhat low requirements for the second rounds of selection procedures for management positions, the possibility of dismissing managers based on a 'sufficient' evaluation result, the possibility of dismissing civil servants based on two service evaluations within a 40-day period, and the deprivation of managers from the possibility of filing an objection against a service evaluation. " At the same time, the European Commissioner notes that the amendment was submitted to the Chamber of Deputies in March 2018 and asks to provide analytical materials that led to its form.

SECTION F:

A trust fund is, according to §1448 et seq. of the Civil Code, an entity without legal personality. It is created by separating the founder's property. The creation of a trust fund creates separate and independent property that has no owner.

Although the ownership rights to the trust fund are exercised by the trustee, it is necessary to be aware that, according to Section 1448(3) of the Civil Code, the ownership rights to the fund do not belong to the trustee, the founder, or the person who is to receive payments from the trust fund.

It cannot be claimed that someone is the owner of the assets in the trust fund. However, it is possible to infer from Ivan Bartoš's speech that he is convinced that Andrej Babiš still has a decisive influence on the assets in the trust fund, even though he is not its owner according to the law.

If this were true, then it could be said that Andrej Babiš is the beneficial owner of the trust fund as understood by Act No. 253/2008 Coll., on certain measures against the legalization of proceeds from crime and the financing of terrorism. According to Section 4(4) of this Act, the beneficial owner of a trust fund would be a person who has the factual or legal ability to exercise direct or indirect decisive influence over the trust fund.

Provided that these conditions are met, there is a rebuttable presumption (" it is presumed that" ) that the beneficial owner of the trust fund is, for example, the founder, trustee or beneficiary. For the sake of completeness, let us state that the Civil Code defines the beneficiary as the person who benefits from the trust fund. This is related to Act No. 304/2013 Coll., on public registers of legal and natural persons, which establishes a register of beneficial owners . However, this register is not a public register.

Although the registered data on the founder and beneficiary of the trust fund are not disclosed without consent, it is possible to conclude that the beneficiary and founder is Andrej Babiš. This is indicated by the publicly available data on the trustees (they are Alexej Bílek and Zbyněk Průša), as well as the findings of Transparency International (see also the graph below, or the table here ).

In connection with this information and other data from the Register of Public Sector Partners, twocomplaints were filed by the Czech Transparency International regarding Babiš's possible conflict of interest. Unlike the register of beneficial owners, the Register of Partners is public and Andrej Babiš appears as one of the ultimate beneficiaries, along with the two aforementioned trustees.

For the sake of completeness, it is necessary to note that the ultimate beneficial owner is a term defined in Section 6a of Act No. 297/2008 Coll. on protection against legalization of proceeds from crime and terrorism. According to the statements of the AGROFERT concern and Andrej Babiš, this term is different from the term beneficial owner under Czech law.

The Minister of the Interior, Mr. Hamáček, who was the Minister of Foreign Affairs at the time, came and said: "There is nothing wrong with that, it is good, we should support it, certainly, it is the right policy of the Czech government to support it." A few weeks later, a new Minister of Foreign Affairs comes from the same party and says: "I will recommend that we actually not support it."
SECTION B: It was not easy for ODS, as a strong party and a long-term traditional party in the Czech political system, not to field a candidate in all 27 districts, and we did it anyway, we did not field one, sometimes we made an agreement, we supported someone else, and what did it ultimately lead to, weakening ODS? No, strengthening it. We won the Senate elections by a landslide.
SECTION C: We are bothered by cooperation with the SPD, and that is why it (massive cooperation, note: Demagog.cz) does not occur. Therefore, there is only one case that I have repeatedly explained publicly and my colleagues from Kladno have also explained, and that is Kladno, where the situation is specific, where it was about choosing the lesser evil under conditions that are clearly given and which mean that no extremist views may have an influence on the governance of Kladno, and it is truly an exception.

SECTION E: In some places, the people who made this political mistake ended their membership in ODS. SECTION F: I set a goal for us (ODS, note: Demagog.cz) to always have 50% more in every election in the same type of election, which is no small ambition, we are doing well, in the last European elections we even exceeded that, when I look at the last elections that were held here, municipal, senate, we significantly strengthened, we clearly won in the senate elections, when I look at the European elections, we were second, we doubled the number of mandates, we tripled the number of votes.

How to determine the vital capacity of the lungs?

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

In Kladno, after gaining 202,233 votes , the Volba pro Kladno party won, as in 2014. It thus won 13 seats in the council, which has a total of 33 members. The party will nevertheless eventually head to the opposition. The parties ODS, SPD, ANO and the Kladeňáci movement have agreed to cooperate, and according to the coalition agreement, Dan Jiránek (ODS), who has already led the city in the past, is to be the mayor.

Petr Fiala stated through a press spokesman that the situation in Kladno " is not entirely standard. " And further: " As far as I know, the campaign in Kladno was very heated, accompanied by massive anonymous attacks on the opposition. " ODS deputy chairman Martin Kupka also pointed out the heated nature of the election campaign and said about cooperation with the SPD: "It is a coalition that I do not prefer, but I understand the arguments that my colleagues (from the Kladno ODS, note: Demagog.cz) presented to the ODS . "

However, not every party leadership is as tolerant of the formation of a coalition with the SPD as the ODS leadership. Petr Hašek , a member of TOP 09 and also a member of the Kladeňáci movement, was faced with the choice of either leaving the coalition or the party. In the end, he decided on the latter option.

The aforementioned escalation of the campaign in Kladno can be proven by the post-election developments . Criminal charges were filed by both the old-new mayor Dan Jiránek from the ODS and representatives of the former mayor Milan Volf (Volba pro Kladno). However, we were unable to find any concrete evidence that would illustrate the escalation of the campaign, nor any credible information about the spreaders of defamatory news.

Kladno is not the only city where the ODS cell deviated from its preferred line; in other cases, however, it is primarily about cooperation with the KSČM. In Hranice, a broad coalition (or rather a " working group aimed at developing the city ") was formed of seven parties and movements that made it to the council. These are ANO, the association Our Beautiful Hranice, Hranice for Life, Hranice 2000, the communists, the ODS with the support of the Free Democrats, and the SPD. In response to criticism (video, 4:41) of cooperation with the KSČM, the six-member local ODS council in Hranice resigned , and the Regional Council proposed revoking the license of the local ODS association in Hranice. Given that the ODS is resolving the coalition in Hranice (although more in connection with cooperation with the KSČM, which regional cells are prohibited from doing), Kladno remains the only tolerated city with a coalition with the SPD.

SECTION B:

At the outset, it should be clarified that Chairman Fiala is talking about Act No. 236/1995 Coll. (abbreviated as the salary of constitutional officials). The so-called automaton , or linking the salary of constitutional officials to the state of the economy, is reflected in the determination of a certain coefficient by which the so-called salary base is multiplied. This is 2.75 times the " average nominal monthly salary of natural persons in the non-business sphere achieved according to published data from the Czech Statistical Office for the calendar year before last " . In other words, for 2019, the salary base is calculated as 2.75 times the average monthly salary for 2017 and determined by the communication of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs.

The above-described machine itself was already part of Act No. 309/2002 Coll., on amendments to laws related to the adoption of the Act on the Service of Civil Servants in Administrative Offices. At that time, the salary base for representatives designated by the Act was to be three times the average monthly wage for the year before last. The purpose of this establishment was actually to establish a " stable link between the salaries of constitutional officials and the development of wages in the non-business sphere " (.doc, p. 36). The procedural history of this provision then consisted primarily in the several postponements of the effectiveness of this act or the annulment of individual provisions of the Act on the Salary of Constitutional Officials by the Constitutional Court. The final amendment to Act No. 359/2014 Coll. from 2014 comes (.pdf) from the pen of Jan Hamáček, the then Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies. The original government proposal (Bohuslav Sobotka's government) envisaged (.pdf) a fixed salary of CZK 52,248 for the next four years, and in the end, Hamáček's amendment was accepted instead.

The new salary range was thus determined by determining a new multiple for deputies (2.75) and a special multiple for judges (3.00). Given the difference between the fixed amount for 2014 and the amount given by the multiple in 2015, Hamáček's proposal provided for a gradual annual increase in the multiple over four years. The salary base should thus reach 2.5 times the average wage for the year before last in 2018.

Petr Fiala and the entire ODS did not vote for either Hamáček's amendment or the final wording of the law . The majority abstained, and in the second vote two deputies were against. Therefore, the expression " we agreed " used by Chairman Fiala in his statement is somewhat questionable.

As for the meaning of the statement about " creating a solution that we will not have to return to ", the amendment may directly imply an effort after 2018 (when the salary was calculated by a multiple of 2.5) to immediately jump to calculating with a multiple of 2.75 in the following year. According to data from Czech Television (infobox note), however, such a procedure would cause the salary of a deputy and senator to increase by 14,700 CZK. The government, which proposed an amendment to the Act on the Salaries of Constitutional Officials, is probably aware of this. It should (.pdf, p. 3) permanently reduce the multiple for the calculation back to 2.5 and also change the average that will be multiplied.

It was also the ODS's votes that moved the proposal from the first reading to committees, which means that the Chamber of Deputies, including the ODS, will consider this proposal and will return to addressing the salaries of MPs, thanks to the ODS.

To summarize the assessment, the timing of the adoption of the amendment is appropriate, but the intention not to return to discussing salaries does not follow from the ODS's vote so far, which concerns the new government draft amendment (the discussion took place on November 15, 2018).

SECTION C:

Fiala refers to the political mistake in the statement as coalition cooperation with the KSČM. The ODS banned such a form of cooperation by adopting a resolution (p. 120) at the 17th Congress in 2006: "The ODS Congress orders the ODS Executive Board to revoke the licenses of local associations that cooperate in coalition with the KSČM at the municipal level."

The ODS statutes state in Article 3, point 7, part f) on termination of membership: " Membership in the party terminates: by cancellation of membership by the local assembly or executive board due to a serious breach of obligations set out in section 3.14 of the statutes or due to a final conviction of a member for an intentional crime." Further in point g): "if the local association terminates and the member does not submit an application for re-registration to another local association within three months of termination."

In Article 7, point 3, part f), the statutes state that the Executive Board's powers are " to decide on the establishment (by granting a license) and the dissolution (by revoking a license) of local associations". In part h), it adds " to decide on the dissolution of membership pursuant to clause 3.7, letter f) of the statutes."

The Executive Board has decided to revoke the licenses of local associations in connection with cooperation with the KSČM several times. In 2011 , the licenses of 18 local associations were revoked. There were 30 local cells that were threatened with having their licenses revoked due to their coalition with the KSČM in 2011. One of the dissolved local associations was the organization in Rychnov nad Kněžnou. However, as the Aktuálně.cz server found out, the cell there eventually reached an agreement with the party leadership and kept its license. This was despite the fact that the ODS members in Rychnov continued to form a coalition with the KSČM. For example, in Týnec nad Sázavou, the party cell was actually dissolved and the representatives continued to exercise their mandate as independents. At the same time, there are known cases where ODS members who entered a coalition with the communists at the local level announced their withdrawal from the ODS and decided to continue in the coalition as independents. This happened, for example, in Aš and Březová .

The ODS Executive Board dealt with the revocation of licenses from local cells due to coalition cooperation with the KSČM, for example, in 2007, when, according to the iRozhlas.cz server, two licenses were revoked in the Olomouc region. Thus, licenses are revoked from party cells in the event of non-compliance with the resolution from the 17th Congress prohibiting cooperation with the KSČM, although in some cases the license was ultimately not revoked.

SECTION D:

In his statement, Fiala draws attention to the different positions of the last two foreign ministers, Hamáček and Petříček, on the Global Compact on Migration.

Jan Hamáček defended the adoption of this document during the discussion in the Chamber of Deputies , stating, among other things: " I will try to explain to the chairman of the ODS club why it is good to have this document, even if it is non-binding."

His successor, Petříček, however, takes the opposite position. In his statement on the Global Compact, for example, he states: " We should therefore withdraw from the compact negotiation process, as the United States, Hungary and Austria did."

So Fiala is right: both ministers had different positions on the Global Compact, which is why we consider the statement to be true.

SECTION E:

Fiala speaks about two things in his statement. According to him, the Global Compact on Migration is a vague document and ceases to distinguish between legal and illegal migration. As a second fact, he states that the same objections to this document are heard from other European countries. We do not take the phrase “most European countries” literally, but only verify whether these views appear in a larger number of countries.

The Global Compact states that this document is not legally binding (p. 2, point 7). This is a declaration that does not contain any sanctions, and this type of document contains general principles rather than specific commitments.

As for the distinction between legal and illegal migration, the Covenant allows states to do so. “ States may distinguish between legal and illegal migration status (...) ” (paragraph 15, p. 4). However, it is a fact that in some points of the document the distinction between these statuses is no longer made. It is best to show this by example. For example, the signatories to the agreement declare in it (paragraph 13 h, p. 21) that they want to “ protect and respect the rights and best interests of the child at all times, regardless of their migration status, by ensuring the availability of viable alternatives to detention in detention facilities. Priority is given to community-based care, ensuring access to education and health care, and respecting the right of children to family life and family unity (...) ”. According to this point, it should not matter to states whether a child entered the country legally or illegally. What matters is the best interests of the child and states should treat both types of child migrants equally.

Now to the very core of our assessment, namely the question of whether similar objections to those of the ODS leader are also being raised in other European countries.

Looking at neighboring Austria , for example, Austrian Chancellor Kurz announced that his country would not join the Global Compact. He stated that the Global Compact does not help to solve migration issues, threatens Austrian sovereignty in matters of migration policy, and blurs the distinction between legal and illegal migration. Austria also raised doubts about the interpretation of certain passages, for example whether the compact can be interpreted as a provision on migration as a human right.

Poland has also announced its intention not to join the Global Compact. Polish Interior Minister Brudzinski stated that the reasons for this step were that " in our opinion, the draft agreement does not guarantee Poland's security. Moreover, it may increase illegal migration . "

The document is also being discussed in Germany . The opposition AfD party, for example, is against its adoption, but there are also critical voices from the ruling CDU/CSU. For example, MP Wendt is concerned about the lack of distinction between refugees and labor migration, while his colleague Mitsch is concerned that the Global Pact " will curtail Germany's sovereignty in migration issues ."

Doubts about the interpretation were also voiced in Estonia , where some political parties demanded that the government clarify the country's political position, i.e. prevent abuse of the ambiguous pact. The Slovak discussion then shows the uncertainty of individual parties and politicians regarding how the Pact can be understood and what obligations it brings to the signatories.

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

Afghanistan borders six countries: China, Iran, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.

If we consider the Czech Republic to be a Western-style democracy where human rights are respected and the country is secular, then none of these countries really come close to it in this regard.

Iran and Pakistan are countries where Islam is the state religion.

Tajikistan , Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan are presidential republics, which nevertheless operate under a more or less authoritarian regime.

China is controlled by the Chinese Communist Party and is constantly criticized for, among other things, human rights violations.

SECTION B:

Despite all the measures taken, Spain and Italy were unable to slow down the coronavirus epidemic for a long time in the spring of this year. In March, the number of deaths in Spain even exceeded the number of victims in China at that time. Subsequently, both countries asked for help from their NATO allies through the Euro -Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre.

This center is now coordinating shipments of medical supplies, such as respirators, masks and ventilators, which are urgently needed by allied countries. In response to this request, the Czech Republic donated 10,000 protective suits to Spain and Italy at the end of March. The shipment of medical supplies was transported by a Spanish military C-130 Hercules aircraft.

The Czech Republic also provided (.pdf) one million protective masks to North Macedonia in April and also showed solidarity with Slovenia, to which it lent 500,000 masks, 25,000 respirators and 5,000 protective suits at the end of March. In April, the Czech Republic then supplied Slovenia with another one million surgical masks and another 200,000 respirators. Last but not least, the Czech Republic also provided part of its air bridge capacity for the transport of medical supplies from other countries, for example to Slovakia .

SECTION C:

From the beginning, the distribution system , in which the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of the Interior were responsible for distribution separately, was criticized primarily by regional governors , healthcare facilities, and the Minister of the Interior, Jan Hamáček. After the arrival of the Ukrainian An-124 Ruslan cargo plane in Pardubice on March 21, 2020, the load was divided on site by firefighters for the Ministry of the Interior and the army for the Ministry of Health.

The government changed the distribution system on Monday, March 23, 2020, in a regulation (.pdf), which expanded the authority of the Ministry of the Interior, which can now supply both state and non-state healthcare facilities.

The central system for distributing protective equipment now covers all target groups, including teaching hospitals, regional hospitals, rescue workers, etc. Firefighters will first deliver supplies to the regions, where the supplies will be distributed to all authorities.

SECTION D:

Whether the hospital bed capacity has already been "drastically increased" is a bit questionable. According to data published by the State Watch , the total number of beds, for example, decreased slightly from October 10 to October 18. However, if we compare the data from the beginning of October to the day of the interview, it cannot be denied that there was a certain increase during this period.

It is also true that hospitals are currently limiting non-acute care , freeing up space for the expected increase in patients with Covid-19. At the same time, the state plans to use beds from state material reserves , some of them for a new facility in Letňany , which the Central Crisis Staff is building with the help of the Czech Army . We can also see a noticeable increase in the number of beds between October 15 and 18 in the presentation (.pdf, p. 9) of Professor Černý.

Current data on free hospital capacities is regularly published by the Institute of Health Information and Statistics, together with a report by the national coordinator of intensive care, Vladimír Černý. His reports show that the bed capacity is sufficient for now. A bigger problem is likely to arise with the shortageof doctors and nurses. First, due to the covid-19 infection, but also due to government measures, as reported by, for example, the Brno University Hospital . The Minister of Health is preparing strategies to replace the missing hospital staff.

SECTION E:

The first information about the order for 1.1 million respirators and 5 million masks from China appeared on March 15 on Jan Hamáček's Twitter account .

According to Aktuálně.cz , this was supposed to happen after Prime Minister Andrej Babiš entrusted the Ministry of the Interior with the purchase of respirators and masks. This is allowed by Act No. 240/2000 Coll. The reason was the inability of the Ministry of Health to order this equipment.

"So we have a fast payment system and I can tell you that we now have more than 30 million masks, 6 million respirators, 250,000 protective biosuits for doctors and medical staff, and 250,000 glasses and shields paid for and under contract in China. This is something that should fundamentally change the situation." This was the statement of the Minister of the Interior on March 17 at a press conference after an extraordinary government meeting. According to this statement, the number of equipment ordered from China has increased.

So far, the latest information with a higher number of protective equipment was heard on March 22 in Václav Moravec's Questions (time 26:25). According to ČTK , the same number announced by Minister Hamáček was also reported by the spokesperson of the Association of Regions of the Czech Republic Pavlíková two days earlier, and the same information was also provided by the Info.cz server, which refers to information requested from the Ministry of the Interior. The only difference here is the number of protective suits, where Info.cz states the number of 300,000, instead of the 250,000 announced by Jan Hamáček.

Information about the contract for face masks, FFP2 respirators, goggles, protective shields, or disposable tests is not searchable in the contract register .

SECTION F:

The competence and appointment process mentioned in the statement are in accordance with the wording of the law and the details regarding the selection procedure correspond to reality (even taking into account the minor numerical deviation, which must be assessed in the context of the statement).

The process of appointing the Director of the General Inspectorate of Security Forces (GIBS) is stated in Section 1, Paragraph 2 of the Act on the General Inspectorate of Security Forces and on Amendments to Related Acts:

“ The Inspectorate is headed by the Director of the Inspectorate (hereinafter referred to as the “Director”), who is appointed and dismissed 1) by the Prime Minister, upon a proposal from the Government and after discussion in the Committee of the Chamber of Deputies responsible for security matters, to whom the Director is accountable for the performance of his/her duties. ”

The vacant position of head of GIBS was vacated after the institution's second-in-command, Michael Murín, decided to resign from his position after disputes with Prime Minister Andrej Babiš, who also imposed disciplinary proceedings against him.

He officially justified his departure by saying that his “ remaining at the head of GIBS could give rise to unjustified questioning of the results of its work. ” 12 candidates applied for the second selection procedure for the post of new director (when the first one was closed due to only one candidate). An independent expert commission subsequently elected Radim Dragoun, the head of the District Prosecutor’s Office in Louny. The Prime Minister fully accepted the commission’s conclusions.

Given the above, we consider the statement to be true, even though there were actually 12 applicants for the position, unlike the 14 mentioned.
